wine_style_description:
Arguably the most famous white wine from Northern Portugal is Vinho Verde (“Green Wine”) from the Minho region in the far north of the country. The other dominant region in Northern Portugal is Douro, which is home to some fabulous port wines.

Northern Portugal is big Alvarinho country, and the wonderfully crisp, almost effervescent Vinho Verde is most commonly made from this grape.

Northern Portugal is known for cheap, refreshing white wines in the coastal areas, and beautiful ports and red table wines inland in the higher ground.

White wine from this region tends to showcase a lot of citrus and, given the close proximity to the Atlantic Ocean, a lot of minerality. Vinho Verde is known for often having a light carbonation that tends to be added after the fermentation.

Wines from these regions are cheap and often represent excellent value for money! The wines live for seafood and go excellently with some cod, a fresh fish taco or a shrimp salad.
grapes: Arinto de Bucelas, Loureiro, Alvarinho, Azal, Avesso, Batoca
interesting_facts: ['The good whites from Northern Portugal are considered among the best value in wine.', 'Some other white grapes from these regions are Arinto, Loureiro, and Trajadura.', 'Portugal is currently the 12th largest wine producing country in the world.']

wine: Herdade do Rocim Olho de Mocho Reserva Branco 2021
wine_style_description:
Southern Portugal is far better known for its reds than its whites, but that doesn't mean that there aren't great bottles to be found. The dryer, hotter climate makes yielding precious acidic wine more challenging than it would be in the north.

The fabulous coastal region of Alentejo produces some excellent wine from the Antão Vaz grape, which is known for being acidic, zesty and tropical fruit-heavy.

Dry and hot are two words that commonly describe the growing regions of Southern Portugal. With as little as 23 inches of rainfall per year and summer temperatures often in excess of 100F, it's easy to see why it's considered difficult to grow great white wine.

While this area is more commonly known for reds, Antão Vaz is a white grape that has won plaudits across the wine world. Thick skinned and often similar to a lightly oaked chardonnay, it's the flagship wine of the Vidigueira region.

The wines of Southern Portugal love seafood, and work extremely well with some fresh fish, nice oily sardines or seafood paella.
grapes: Malvasia, Fernao Pires
interesting_facts: ["The Alentejo region is far more well known for producing grain, and is unofficially called Portugal's “bread basket”.", 'Portugal is currently the 12th largest wine producing country in the world.', "Southern Portugal is far better known for producing cork than producing wine. It makes over one third of the world's natural bottle stoppers."]
flavor_words: tree_fruit, oak, citrus_fruit, microbio, non_oak, earth, spices, tropical_fruit, floral, vegetal, dried_fruit, red_fruit

wine_style_description:
Vinho Verde is a widely consumed white wine from Northern Portugal. The wine tends to be made from local grapes such as Alvarinho (Albarino), Loureiro, Arinto, and Azal.

Vinho Verde is a light, refreshing wine with lots of floral and green fruit notes. The wine often has a slight carbonation to it, though not enough that it could be referred to as a sparkling wine.

A Vinho Verde region was established in 1908, though the area didn't receive its Denominação de Origem Controlada (DOC) until 1984. The wine is thought to have originated in the Minho province in the far north of Portugal.

The carbonation in the bottle occurs from a process called malolactic fermentation, and while this is typically considered to be a defect in the wine the Vinho Verde producers found that the consumers rather liked it.

Because of the wine's bracing acidity and oceanic minerality it should be considered to be the ultimate partner to raw shellfish.
grapes: Arinto de Bucelas, Loureiro, Alvarinho, Azal, Avesso, Batoca
interesting_facts: ['Growers quite often plant their vines of telephone poles of large walls in order to grow fruit and vegetables beneath the vines.', 'Vinho Verde is a wine intended to be consumed young.', "15% of Portugal's natural viticultural area is dedicated to the production of Vinho Verde."]

wine_style_description:
The Alentejo region covers approximately a third of Portugal, producing red wines that are easy-drinking and fruit-forward.

Aragonez is the most widely-planted red grape in the region, which produces full-bodied, budget friendly red wines. Castelao, Trincadeira are also widely planted. Frequently, wines from this region are blends of several grapes.

Although traditional Portuguese grape varieties dominate the region, many red wines from Alentejo also incorporate international grape varieties such as Syrah and Cabernet Sauvignon.

The region produces ripe, full bodied and fruit forward wines that are a product of the hot, inland region. The wines are often described as “New World” in style.

Due to the reliable climate, wines from Alentejo combine quality with affordability, offering great bang for the buck. It offers some of the best value and quality for the money of any European wine region.

Wine from this region pairs excellently with hearty, full-bodied dishes.
grapes: Aragonez, Castelao, Trincadeira
interesting_facts: ['Aragonez, the most widely planted grape in Alentejo region, is also known as Tempranillo.', 'Vineyard land in Alentejo is among the most expensive in all of Portugal.', 'The region of Alentejo is noted for its extensive cork production.']
flavor_words: oak, black_fruit, non_oak, spices, earth, red_fruit, microbio, dried_fruit, floral, vegetal, citrus_fruit, tree_fruit, tropical_fruit

wine_style_description:
Southern Portugal is far better known for its reds than its whites, but that doesn't mean that there aren't great bottles to be found. The dryer, hotter climate makes yielding precious acidic wine more challenging than it would be in the north.

The fabulous coastal region of Alentejo produces some excellent wine from the Antão Vaz grape, which is known for being acidic, zesty and tropical fruit-heavy.

Dry and hot are two words that commonly describe the growing regions of Southern Portugal. With as little as 23 inches of rainfall per year and summer temperatures often in excess of 100F, it's easy to see why it's considered difficult to grow great white wine.

While this area is more commonly known for reds, Antão Vaz is a white grape that has won plaudits across the wine world. Thick skinned and often similar to a lightly oaked chardonnay, it's the flagship wine of the Vidigueira region.

The wines of Southern Portugal love seafood, and work extremely well with some fresh fish, nice oily sardines or seafood paella.
grapes: Malvasia, Fernao Pires
interesting_facts: ["The Alentejo region is far more well known for producing grain, and is unofficially called Portugal's “bread basket”.", 'Portugal is currently the 12th largest wine producing country in the world.', "Southern Portugal is far better known for producing cork than producing wine. It makes over one third of the world's natural bottle stoppers."]
flavor_words: tree_fruit, earth

wine_style_description:
The Alentejo region covers approximately a third of Portugal, producing red wines that are easy-drinking and fruit-forward.

Aragonez is the most widely-planted red grape in the region, which produces full-bodied, budget friendly red wines. Castelao, Trincadeira are also widely planted. Frequently, wines from this region are blends of several grapes.

Although traditional Portuguese grape varieties dominate the region, many red wines from Alentejo also incorporate international grape varieties such as Syrah and Cabernet Sauvignon.

The region produces ripe, full bodied and fruit forward wines that are a product of the hot, inland region. The wines are often described as “New World” in style.

Due to the reliable climate, wines from Alentejo combine quality with affordability, offering great bang for the buck. It offers some of the best value and quality for the money of any European wine region.

Wine from this region pairs excellently with hearty, full-bodied dishes.
grapes: Aragonez, Castelao, Trincadeira
interesting_facts: ['Aragonez, the most widely planted grape in Alentejo region, is also known as Tempranillo.', 'Vineyard land in Alentejo is among the most expensive in all of Portugal.', 'The region of Alentejo is noted for its extensive cork production.']
flavor_words: black_fruit, red_fruit, oak, spices, non_oak, earth, tree_fruit, microbio, dried_fruit

wine_style_description:
Dão red wines come from a wide variety of grapes. They include Touriga Nacional, Alfrocheiro, Tinta Roriz, Jaen, Baga, Bastardo and Tinta Pinheira. The wines can range from thin to full-bodied due to multiple altitudes that these wines are grown in.

The wines normally are packed with plum and cherry flavors which are supported by firm tannins. They pair well with a wide range of food making them an easy choice for a dinner.

Being surrounded by mountains on all sides has its advantages. The Dão region is protected from the climate of the continent and from the ocean. The elevation also gives the wine much of its character. Elevation ranges between 600 feet to 3,000 feet at some points.

Most vineyards have small plots dotted through various hillsides and elevations. The soil is very poor making for stronger vines that can survive the shifts from cool nights to hot days.

The region is still considered off the beaten path and great value can be found in many of the wines. The lusher wines have the ability to age for up to 20 years or possibly more.
grapes: Touriga Nacional
interesting_facts: ['Dão nobre (means noble Dão), this is saved for reserve wines.', 'Garrafeira requires wines to be 0.5% higher in alcohol and requires two or more years spent in oak.', 'Tinta Roriz is an indigenous grape to the region. In Spain it is known as Tempranillo.', 'Touriga Nacional, the main component of port, originated in this region.']
flavor_words: black_fruit, spices, dried_fruit, earth, oak, red_fruit, non_oak, microbio, tree_fruit, floral

wine_style_description:
Just like in the north, the red wines of Southern Portugal are experiencing a Renaissance right now. These wines are typically fruity and easy to enjoy.

The regions of Alentejo and Ribatejo are leading the charge making delicious wine that anyone can enjoy.

While Northern Portugal is making amazing wines in small quantities, Southern Portugal is producing delicious, easy-drinking red wines in large quantities.

The region of Alentejo is on the forefront of this movement. The sprawling farms have allowed them to make soft, delicious wines from local grape varieties.

The region of Ribatejo is also making approachable, fun wines, but they use French grapes much more than Alentejo. Cabernet Sauvignon, Syrah, and Merlot are often found along with local grapes. White grapes are still more common in the area, but there is so much potential in the red wines.
grapes: Baga, Castelao
interesting_facts: ["Over half of the world's supply of cork is grown in Portugal.", 'With its bulk wine production, the region of Estremadura produces more wine than any other region in Portugal.', 'The region of Estremadura is known locally as Oeste, which means West.', 'The soil in much of Southern Portugal is alluvial, which is very fertile and perfect for getting lots of fruit.', 'Traditional wine in the Alentejo region is aged in clay pots.', 'A large portion of the wine in Southern Portugal is made in cooperatives that make wine for many producers at the same time.']
flavor_words: black_fruit, oak, spices, earth, non_oak, red_fruit, dried_fruit, microbio, floral, citrus_fruit, vegetal

wine_style_description:
Douro Red wines range in style from light and fruity to lush and smooth to dark and dense with flavors of mature dark fruit, with herbal and schist.

The wines are often and inky purple due to the thickening of the skins from the intense summer heat of the region.

Most of the best made reds from the region come from the larger port houses where the skill of the winemakers go back for generations. The wines tend to be an incredible value for the time being but costs are slowly increasing due to the amazing blends coming from the area.

The first time one sees the Douro region they will always ask themselves, how can wine be made in such rugged terrain. It is also an amazingly beautiful area, with hillsides covered in terraced vineyards. Most larger winemakers have also started converting their areas into tourist destinations and wine hotels.

Grapes include the Touriga Francesa, Tinta Roriz, Touriga Nacional and Tinta Barroca. Older vineyards still contain many less used vine varieties which makes their annual efforts less predictable, but allowing for unexpected surprises yielding unique, complex wines.
grapes: Touriga Nacional, Tinta Roriz, Touriga Francesa
interesting_facts: ['The Douro Valley is the home of Port wine.', 'There is evidence as early as the 3rd century AD of winegrowing in the region.', 'Temperatures in the Douro Valley often reach above 100 degrees F in the summer months. This lends to the inky color of the red wines, whose skin is thicker than cool climate grapes.']
flavor_words: red_fruit, citrus_fruit, spices

wine_style_description:
Arguably the most famous white wine from Northern Portugal is Vinho Verde (“Green Wine”) from the Minho region in the far north of the country. The other dominant region in Northern Portugal is Douro, which is home to some fabulous port wines.

Northern Portugal is big Alvarinho country, and the wonderfully crisp, almost effervescent Vinho Verde is most commonly made from this grape.

Northern Portugal is known for cheap, refreshing white wines in the coastal areas, and beautiful ports and red table wines inland in the higher ground.

White wine from this region tends to showcase a lot of citrus and, given the close proximity to the Atlantic Ocean, a lot of minerality. Vinho Verde is known for often having a light carbonation that tends to be added after the fermentation.

Wines from these regions are cheap and often represent excellent value for money! The wines live for seafood and go excellently with some cod, a fresh fish taco or a shrimp salad.
grapes: Arinto de Bucelas, Loureiro, Alvarinho, Azal, Avesso, Batoca
interesting_facts: ['The good whites from Northern Portugal are considered among the best value in wine.', 'Some other white grapes from these regions are Arinto, Loureiro, and Trajadura.', 'Portugal is currently the 12th largest wine producing country in the world.']
suggested_food_pairining: Shellfish, Appetizers and snacks, Lean fish, Cured Meat

wine: Quinta Vale D. Maria Reserva Porto 2018
wine_style_description:
Produced exclusively in the Douro Valley of Northern Portugal, Port wine with its unique characteristics has become a favorite the world over.

There are scores of  different grape varieties used in the production of port. This wine is more about the production methods used and the fortification with spirit than the nuances that the fruit has to offer.

Port is fortified. This means that there is an introduction of some type of distilled spirit to the wine during production. These wines can achieve an ABV of 20% or more.

You will encounter one of two main types of port. The first, Ruby Port, is the most common. It has a deep ruby color, is sweet, and has relatively little exposure to oak. Tawny Port is brown in color, is aged longer, and draws its color and character from longer exposure to oak.

This wine is commonly used for desserts or a night-cap. Vintage ports, with an actual year of production i.e 1985, are far less common and usually quite spendy. Most ports are associated with a length of time of aging, like a 4-year port, or 10-year port.
grapes: Touriga Nacional, Tinta Roriz, Tinta Barroca, Souzao, Touriga Francesa
interesting_facts: ['Only wine from the Douro Valley of Portugal can legally be called Port.', 'Barrels are recycled. When you buy a ten-year port, that means the youngest juice in the barrel is ten years old. in actuality, you could be drinking wine that is many decades older.', 'One of the most traditional and delicious pairings in all the wine drinking world is Port and blue cheese.']
suggested_food_pairining: Sweet desserts, Mature and hard cheese, Blue cheese
flavor_words: black_fruit, oak, red_fruit, non_oak, spices, earth, dried_fruit, microbio, tree_fruit, citrus_fruit, floral

wine_style_description:
Vinho Verde is a widely consumed white wine from Northern Portugal. The wine tends to be made from local grapes such as Alvarinho (Albarino), Loureiro, Arinto, and Azal.

Vinho Verde is a light, refreshing wine with lots of floral and green fruit notes. The wine often has a slight carbonation to it, though not enough that it could be referred to as a sparkling wine.

A Vinho Verde region was established in 1908, though the area didn't receive its Denominação de Origem Controlada (DOC) until 1984. The wine is thought to have originated in the Minho province in the far north of Portugal.

The carbonation in the bottle occurs from a process called malolactic fermentation, and while this is typically considered to be a defect in the wine the Vinho Verde producers found that the consumers rather liked it.

Because of the wine's bracing acidity and oceanic minerality it should be considered to be the ultimate partner to raw shellfish.
grapes: Arinto de Bucelas, Loureiro, Alvarinho, Azal, Avesso, Batoca
interesting_facts: ['Growers quite often plant their vines of telephone poles of large walls in order to grow fruit and vegetables beneath the vines.', 'Vinho Verde is a wine intended to be consumed young.', "15% of Portugal's natural viticultural area is dedicated to the production of Vinho Verde."]
flavor_words: tree_fruit, citrus_fruit, earth, tropical_fruit, microbio, non_oak, oak, vegetal, floral, dried_fruit, spices, black_fruit, red_fruit

Vinho Verde is a light, refreshing wine with lots of floral and green fruit notes. The wine often has a slight carbonation to it, though not enough that it could be referred to as a sparkling wine.

A Vinho Verde region was established in 1908, though the area didn't receive its Denominação de Origem Controlada (DOC) until 1984. The wine is thought to have originated in the Minho province in the far north of Portugal.

The carbonation in the bottle occurs from a process called malolactic fermentation, and while this is typically considered to be a defect in the wine the Vinho Verde producers found that the consumers rather liked it.

Because of the wine's bracing acidity and oceanic minerality it should be considered to be the ultimate partner to raw shellfish.
grapes: Arinto de Bucelas, Loureiro, Alvarinho, Azal, Avesso, Batoca
interesting_facts: ['Growers quite often plant their vines of telephone poles of large walls in order to grow fruit and vegetables beneath the vines.', 'Vinho Verde is a wine intended to be consumed young.', "15% of Portugal's natural viticultural area is dedicated to the production of Vinho Verde."]
flavor_words: citrus_fruit, earth, tree_fruit, vegetal, tropical_fruit, microbio, oak, floral, non_oak

wine_style_description:
Just like in the north, the red wines of Southern Portugal are experiencing a Renaissance right now. These wines are typically fruity and easy to enjoy.

The regions of Alentejo and Ribatejo are leading the charge making delicious wine that anyone can enjoy.

While Northern Portugal is making amazing wines in small quantities, Southern Portugal is producing delicious, easy-drinking red wines in large quantities.

The region of Alentejo is on the forefront of this movement. The sprawling farms have allowed them to make soft, delicious wines from local grape varieties.

The region of Ribatejo is also making approachable, fun wines, but they use French grapes much more than Alentejo. Cabernet Sauvignon, Syrah, and Merlot are often found along with local grapes. White grapes are still more common in the area, but there is so much potential in the red wines.
grapes: Baga, Castelao
interesting_facts: ["Over half of the world's supply of cork is grown in Portugal.", 'With its bulk wine production, the region of Estremadura produces more wine than any other region in Portugal.', 'The region of Estremadura is known locally as Oeste, which means West.', 'The soil in much of Southern Portugal is alluvial, which is very fertile and perfect for getting lots of fruit.', 'Traditional wine in the Alentejo region is aged in clay pots.', 'A large portion of the wine in Southern Portugal is made in cooperatives that make wine for many producers at the same time.']

wine: Adega Mayor Reserva do Comendador Branco 2020
wine_style_description:
Southern Portugal is far better known for its reds than its whites, but that doesn't mean that there aren't great bottles to be found. The dryer, hotter climate makes yielding precious acidic wine more challenging than it would be in the north.

The fabulous coastal region of Alentejo produces some excellent wine from the Antão Vaz grape, which is known for being acidic, zesty and tropical fruit-heavy.

Dry and hot are two words that commonly describe the growing regions of Southern Portugal. With as little as 23 inches of rainfall per year and summer temperatures often in excess of 100F, it's easy to see why it's considered difficult to grow great white wine.

While this area is more commonly known for reds, Antão Vaz is a white grape that has won plaudits across the wine world. Thick skinned and often similar to a lightly oaked chardonnay, it's the flagship wine of the Vidigueira region.

The wines of Southern Portugal love seafood, and work extremely well with some fresh fish, nice oily sardines or seafood paella.
grapes: Malvasia, Fernao Pires
interesting_facts: ["The Alentejo region is far more well known for producing grain, and is unofficially called Portugal's “bread basket”.", 'Portugal is currently the 12th largest wine producing country in the world.', "Southern Portugal is far better known for producing cork than producing wine. It makes over one third of the world's natural bottle stoppers."]

flavor_words: tree_fruit, oak, earth, microbio, tropical_fruit, citrus_fruit

wine_style_description:
Arguably the most famous white wine from Northern Portugal is Vinho Verde (“Green Wine”) from the Minho region in the far north of the country. The other dominant region in Northern Portugal is Douro, which is home to some fabulous port wines.

Northern Portugal is big Alvarinho country, and the wonderfully crisp, almost effervescent Vinho Verde is most commonly made from this grape.

Northern Portugal is known for cheap, refreshing white wines in the coastal areas, and beautiful ports and red table wines inland in the higher ground.

White wine from this region tends to showcase a lot of citrus and, given the close proximity to the Atlantic Ocean, a lot of minerality. Vinho Verde is known for often having a light carbonation that tends to be added after the fermentation.

Wines from these regions are cheap and often represent excellent value for money! The wines live for seafood and go excellently with some cod, a fresh fish taco or a shrimp salad.
grapes: Arinto de Bucelas, Loureiro, Alvarinho, Azal, Avesso, Batoca
interesting_facts: ['The good whites from Northern Portugal are considered among the best value in wine.', 'Some other white grapes from these regions are Arinto, Loureiro, and Trajadura.', 'Portugal is currently the 12th largest wine producing country in the world.']
suggested_food_pairining: Shellfish, Appetizers and snacks, Lean fish, Cured Meat
flavor_words: citrus_fruit, tree_fruit, oak, tropical_fruit, spices, vegetal, earth, non_oak

wine_style_description:
Douro Red wines range in style from light and fruity to lush and smooth to dark and dense with flavors of mature dark fruit, with herbal and schist.

The wines are often and inky purple due to the thickening of the skins from the intense summer heat of the region.

Most of the best made reds from the region come from the larger port houses where the skill of the winemakers go back for generations. The wines tend to be an incredible value for the time being but costs are slowly increasing due to the amazing blends coming from the area.

The first time one sees the Douro region they will always ask themselves, how can wine be made in such rugged terrain. It is also an amazingly beautiful area, with hillsides covered in terraced vineyards. Most larger winemakers have also started converting their areas into tourist destinations and wine hotels.

Grapes include the Touriga Francesa, Tinta Roriz, Touriga Nacional and Tinta Barroca. Older vineyards still contain many less used vine varieties which makes their annual efforts less predictable, but allowing for unexpected surprises yielding unique, complex wines.
grapes: Touriga Nacional, Tinta Roriz, Touriga Francesa
interesting_facts: ['The Douro Valley is the home of Port wine.', 'There is evidence as early as the 3rd century AD of winegrowing in the region.', 'Temperatures in the Douro Valley often reach above 100 degrees F in the summer months. This lends to the inky color of the red wines, whose skin is thicker than cool climate grapes.']
flavor_words: oak, red_fruit, non_oak, earth, black_fruit, spices, microbio

wine_style_description:
Dão red wines come from a wide variety of grapes. They include Touriga Nacional, Alfrocheiro, Tinta Roriz, Jaen, Baga, Bastardo and Tinta Pinheira. The wines can range from thin to full-bodied due to multiple altitudes that these wines are grown in.

The wines normally are packed with plum and cherry flavors which are supported by firm tannins. They pair well with a wide range of food making them an easy choice for a dinner.

Being surrounded by mountains on all sides has its advantages. The Dão region is protected from the climate of the continent and from the ocean. The elevation also gives the wine much of its character. Elevation ranges between 600 feet to 3,000 feet at some points.

Most vineyards have small plots dotted through various hillsides and elevations. The soil is very poor making for stronger vines that can survive the shifts from cool nights to hot days.

The region is still considered off the beaten path and great value can be found in many of the wines. The lusher wines have the ability to age for up to 20 years or possibly more.
grapes: Touriga Nacional
interesting_facts: ['Dão nobre (means noble Dão), this is saved for reserve wines.', 'Garrafeira requires wines to be 0.5% higher in alcohol and requires two or more years spent in oak.', 'Tinta Roriz is an indigenous grape to the region. In Spain it is known as Tempranillo.', 'Touriga Nacional, the main component of port, originated in this region.']
flavor_words: black_fruit, oak, earth, non_oak, red_fruit, spices, floral, microbio, vegetal

suggested_food_pairining: Shellfish, Appetizers and snacks, Cured Meat

flavor_words: non_oak, oak, dried_fruit, earth, microbio, black_fruit, vegetal, red_fruit, tree_fruit, spices, citrus_fruit

wine_style_description:
The Alentejo region covers approximately a third of Portugal, producing red wines that are easy-drinking and fruit-forward.

Aragonez is the most widely-planted red grape in the region, which produces full-bodied, budget friendly red wines. Castelao, Trincadeira are also widely planted. Frequently, wines from this region are blends of several grapes.

Although traditional Portuguese grape varieties dominate the region, many red wines from Alentejo also incorporate international grape varieties such as Syrah and Cabernet Sauvignon.

The region produces ripe, full bodied and fruit forward wines that are a product of the hot, inland region. The wines are often described as “New World” in style.

Due to the reliable climate, wines from Alentejo combine quality with affordability, offering great bang for the buck. It offers some of the best value and quality for the money of any European wine region.

Wine from this region pairs excellently with hearty, full-bodied dishes.
grapes: Aragonez, Castelao, Trincadeira
interesting_facts: ['Aragonez, the most widely planted grape in Alentejo region, is also known as Tempranillo.', 'Vineyard land in Alentejo is among the most expensive in all of Portugal.', 'The region of Alentejo is noted for its extensive cork production.']
flavor_words: oak, black_fruit, non_oak, spices, earth, red_fruit, microbio, dried_fruit, floral, vegetal, citrus_fruit, tree_fruit, tropical_fruit

suggested_food_pairining: Appetizers and snacks, Fruity desserts, Aperitif, Cured Meat
flavor_words: citrus_fruit, tree_fruit, earth, spices, tropical_fruit, floral, microbio, oak, non_oak, black_fruit, dried_fruit, vegetal

wine_style_description:
Douro Red wines range in style from light and fruity to lush and smooth to dark and dense with flavors of mature dark fruit, with herbal and schist.

The wines are often and inky purple due to the thickening of the skins from the intense summer heat of the region.

Most of the best made reds from the region come from the larger port houses where the skill of the winemakers go back for generations. The wines tend to be an incredible value for the time being but costs are slowly increasing due to the amazing blends coming from the area.

The first time one sees the Douro region they will always ask themselves, how can wine be made in such rugged terrain. It is also an amazingly beautiful area, with hillsides covered in terraced vineyards. Most larger winemakers have also started converting their areas into tourist destinations and wine hotels.

Grapes include the Touriga Francesa, Tinta Roriz, Touriga Nacional and Tinta Barroca. Older vineyards still contain many less used vine varieties which makes their annual efforts less predictable, but allowing for unexpected surprises yielding unique, complex wines.
grapes: Touriga Nacional, Tinta Roriz, Touriga Francesa
interesting_facts: ['The Douro Valley is the home of Port wine.', 'There is evidence as early as the 3rd century AD of winegrowing in the region.', 'Temperatures in the Douro Valley often reach above 100 degrees F in the summer months. This lends to the inky color of the red wines, whose skin is thicker than cool climate grapes.']
flavor_words: oak, red_fruit, earth, non_oak, spices, black_fruit, dried_fruit, vegetal, microbio

wine: Adega Mayor Reserva do Comendador Branco 2021
wine_style_description:
Southern Portugal is far better known for its reds than its whites, but that doesn't mean that there aren't great bottles to be found. The dryer, hotter climate makes yielding precious acidic wine more challenging than it would be in the north.

The fabulous coastal region of Alentejo produces some excellent wine from the Antão Vaz grape, which is known for being acidic, zesty and tropical fruit-heavy.

Dry and hot are two words that commonly describe the growing regions of Southern Portugal. With as little as 23 inches of rainfall per year and summer temperatures often in excess of 100F, it's easy to see why it's considered difficult to grow great white wine.

While this area is more commonly known for reds, Antão Vaz is a white grape that has won plaudits across the wine world. Thick skinned and often similar to a lightly oaked chardonnay, it's the flagship wine of the Vidigueira region.

The wines of Southern Portugal love seafood, and work extremely well with some fresh fish, nice oily sardines or seafood paella.
grapes: Malvasia, Fernao Pires
interesting_facts: ["The Alentejo region is far more well known for producing grain, and is unofficially called Portugal's “bread basket”.", 'Portugal is currently the 12th largest wine producing country in the world.', "Southern Portugal is far better known for producing cork than producing wine. It makes over one third of the world's natural bottle stoppers."]
flavor_words: oak, citrus_fruit, tree_fruit, microbio, non_oak, tropical_fruit, earth, spices, vegetal, red_fruit, floral, black_fruit

wine_style_description:
Just like in the north, the red wines of Southern Portugal are experiencing a Renaissance right now. These wines are typically fruity and easy to enjoy.

The regions of Alentejo and Ribatejo are leading the charge making delicious wine that anyone can enjoy.

While Northern Portugal is making amazing wines in small quantities, Southern Portugal is producing delicious, easy-drinking red wines in large quantities.

The region of Alentejo is on the forefront of this movement. The sprawling farms have allowed them to make soft, delicious wines from local grape varieties.

The region of Ribatejo is also making approachable, fun wines, but they use French grapes much more than Alentejo. Cabernet Sauvignon, Syrah, and Merlot are often found along with local grapes. White grapes are still more common in the area, but there is so much potential in the red wines.
grapes: Baga, Castelao
interesting_facts: ["Over half of the world's supply of cork is grown in Portugal.", 'With its bulk wine production, the region of Estremadura produces more wine than any other region in Portugal.', 'The region of Estremadura is known locally as Oeste, which means West.', 'The soil in much of Southern Portugal is alluvial, which is very fertile and perfect for getting lots of fruit.', 'Traditional wine in the Alentejo region is aged in clay pots.', 'A large portion of the wine in Southern Portugal is made in cooperatives that make wine for many producers at the same time.']
flavor_words: oak, spices, black_fruit, non_oak, red_fruit, floral, earth, microbio, dried_fruit

grapes: Touriga Nacional, Touriga Franca, Tinta Roriz

flavor_words: black_fruit, oak, dried_fruit, red_fruit, earth, non_oak, spices, microbio, vegetal, floral

wine_style_description:
Arguably the most famous white wine from Northern Portugal is Vinho Verde (“Green Wine”) from the Minho region in the far north of the country. The other dominant region in Northern Portugal is Douro, which is home to some fabulous port wines.

Northern Portugal is big Alvarinho country, and the wonderfully crisp, almost effervescent Vinho Verde is most commonly made from this grape.

Northern Portugal is known for cheap, refreshing white wines in the coastal areas, and beautiful ports and red table wines inland in the higher ground.

White wine from this region tends to showcase a lot of citrus and, given the close proximity to the Atlantic Ocean, a lot of minerality. Vinho Verde is known for often having a light carbonation that tends to be added after the fermentation.

Wines from these regions are cheap and often represent excellent value for money! The wines live for seafood and go excellently with some cod, a fresh fish taco or a shrimp salad.
grapes: Arinto de Bucelas, Loureiro, Alvarinho, Azal, Avesso, Batoca
interesting_facts: ['The good whites from Northern Portugal are considered among the best value in wine.', 'Some other white grapes from these regions are Arinto, Loureiro, and Trajadura.', 'Portugal is currently the 12th largest wine producing country in the world.']
suggested_food_pairining: Shellfish, Appetizers and snacks, Lean fish, Cured Meat
flavor_words: tree_fruit, earth, oak, citrus_fruit, microbio, non_oak, spices, vegetal, tropical_fruit, floral, dried_fruit, black_fruit, red_fruit

wine: Casa da Passarella O Oenólogo Vinhas Velhas 2014
wine_style_description:
Dão red wines come from a wide variety of grapes. They include Touriga Nacional, Alfrocheiro, Tinta Roriz, Jaen, Baga, Bastardo and Tinta Pinheira. The wines can range from thin to full-bodied due to multiple altitudes that these wines are grown in.

The wines normally are packed with plum and cherry flavors which are supported by firm tannins. They pair well with a wide range of food making them an easy choice for a dinner.

Being surrounded by mountains on all sides has its advantages. The Dão region is protected from the climate of the continent and from the ocean. The elevation also gives the wine much of its character. Elevation ranges between 600 feet to 3,000 feet at some points.

Most vineyards have small plots dotted through various hillsides and elevations. The soil is very poor making for stronger vines that can survive the shifts from cool nights to hot days.

The region is still considered off the beaten path and great value can be found in many of the wines. The lusher wines have the ability to age for up to 20 years or possibly more.
grapes: Touriga Nacional
interesting_facts: ['Dão nobre (means noble Dão), this is saved for reserve wines.', 'Garrafeira requires wines to be 0.5% higher in alcohol and requires two or more years spent in oak.', 'Tinta Roriz is an indigenous grape to the region. In Spain it is known as Tempranillo.', 'Touriga Nacional, the main component of port, originated in this region.']
flavor_words: black_fruit, oak, earth, red_fruit, non_oak, spices, microbio, citrus_fruit, vegetal, dried_fruit, floral

wine: Howard's Folly Edição Especial Dirk Niepoort 2019
wine_style_description:
The Alentejo region covers approximately a third of Portugal, producing red wines that are easy-drinking and fruit-forward.

Aragonez is the most widely-planted red grape in the region, which produces full-bodied, budget friendly red wines. Castelao, Trincadeira are also widely planted. Frequently, wines from this region are blends of several grapes.

Although traditional Portuguese grape varieties dominate the region, many red wines from Alentejo also incorporate international grape varieties such as Syrah and Cabernet Sauvignon.

The region produces ripe, full bodied and fruit forward wines that are a product of the hot, inland region. The wines are often described as “New World” in style.

Due to the reliable climate, wines from Alentejo combine quality with affordability, offering great bang for the buck. It offers some of the best value and quality for the money of any European wine region.

Wine from this region pairs excellently with hearty, full-bodied dishes.
grapes: Aragonez, Castelao, Trincadeira
interesting_facts: ['Aragonez, the most widely planted grape in Alentejo region, is also known as Tempranillo.', 'Vineyard land in Alentejo is among the most expensive in all of Portugal.', 'The region of Alentejo is noted for its extensive cork production.']

The wines are often and inky purple due to the thickening of the skins from the intense summer heat of the region.

wine_style_description:
Just like in the north, the red wines of Southern Portugal are experiencing a Renaissance right now. These wines are typically fruity and easy to enjoy.

The regions of Alentejo and Ribatejo are leading the charge making delicious wine that anyone can enjoy.

While Northern Portugal is making amazing wines in small quantities, Southern Portugal is producing delicious, easy-drinking red wines in large quantities.

The region of Alentejo is on the forefront of this movement. The sprawling farms have allowed them to make soft, delicious wines from local grape varieties.

The region of Ribatejo is also making approachable, fun wines, but they use French grapes much more than Alentejo. Cabernet Sauvignon, Syrah, and Merlot are often found along with local grapes. White grapes are still more common in the area, but there is so much potential in the red wines.
grapes: Baga, Castelao
interesting_facts: ["Over half of the world's supply of cork is grown in Portugal.", 'With its bulk wine production, the region of Estremadura produces more wine than any other region in Portugal.', 'The region of Estremadura is known locally as Oeste, which means West.', 'The soil in much of Southern Portugal is alluvial, which is very fertile and perfect for getting lots of fruit.', 'Traditional wine in the Alentejo region is aged in clay pots.', 'A large portion of the wine in Southern Portugal is made in cooperatives that make wine for many producers at the same time.']

wine_style_description:
Arguably the most famous white wine from Northern Portugal is Vinho Verde (“Green Wine”) from the Minho region in the far north of the country. The other dominant region in Northern Portugal is Douro, which is home to some fabulous port wines.

Northern Portugal is big Alvarinho country, and the wonderfully crisp, almost effervescent Vinho Verde is most commonly made from this grape.

Northern Portugal is known for cheap, refreshing white wines in the coastal areas, and beautiful ports and red table wines inland in the higher ground.

White wine from this region tends to showcase a lot of citrus and, given the close proximity to the Atlantic Ocean, a lot of minerality. Vinho Verde is known for often having a light carbonation that tends to be added after the fermentation.

Wines from these regions are cheap and often represent excellent value for money! The wines live for seafood and go excellently with some cod, a fresh fish taco or a shrimp salad.
grapes: Arinto de Bucelas, Loureiro, Alvarinho, Azal, Avesso, Batoca
interesting_facts: ['The good whites from Northern Portugal are considered among the best value in wine.', 'Some other white grapes from these regions are Arinto, Loureiro, and Trajadura.', 'Portugal is currently the 12th largest wine producing country in the world.']
suggested_food_pairining: Shellfish, Appetizers and snacks, Lean fish, Cured Meat

wine: Bacalhôa Península de Setúbal Quinta da Bacalhôa Branco 2019
wine_style_description:
Southern Portugal is far better known for its reds than its whites, but that doesn't mean that there aren't great bottles to be found. The dryer, hotter climate makes yielding precious acidic wine more challenging than it would be in the north.

The fabulous coastal region of Alentejo produces some excellent wine from the Antão Vaz grape, which is known for being acidic, zesty and tropical fruit-heavy.

Dry and hot are two words that commonly describe the growing regions of Southern Portugal. With as little as 23 inches of rainfall per year and summer temperatures often in excess of 100F, it's easy to see why it's considered difficult to grow great white wine.

While this area is more commonly known for reds, Antão Vaz is a white grape that has won plaudits across the wine world. Thick skinned and often similar to a lightly oaked chardonnay, it's the flagship wine of the Vidigueira region.

The wines of Southern Portugal love seafood, and work extremely well with some fresh fish, nice oily sardines or seafood paella.
grapes: Malvasia, Fernao Pires
interesting_facts: ["The Alentejo region is far more well known for producing grain, and is unofficially called Portugal's “bread basket”.", 'Portugal is currently the 12th largest wine producing country in the world.', "Southern Portugal is far better known for producing cork than producing wine. It makes over one third of the world's natural bottle stoppers."]
flavor_words: oak, tree_fruit, earth, citrus_fruit, tropical_fruit, spices, non_oak, microbio, vegetal, floral, red_fruit, dried_fruit, black_fruit

wine: A&D Wines - Quinta de Santa Teresa Esculpido Branco 2019
winery: A&D Wines - Quinta de Santa Teresa
wine_style_description:
Vinho Verde is a widely consumed white wine from Northern Portugal. The wine tends to be made from local grapes such as Alvarinho (Albarino), Loureiro, Arinto, and Azal.

Vinho Verde is a light, refreshing wine with lots of floral and green fruit notes. The wine often has a slight carbonation to it, though not enough that it could be referred to as a sparkling wine.

A Vinho Verde region was established in 1908, though the area didn't receive its Denominação de Origem Controlada (DOC) until 1984. The wine is thought to have originated in the Minho province in the far north of Portugal.

The carbonation in the bottle occurs from a process called malolactic fermentation, and while this is typically considered to be a defect in the wine the Vinho Verde producers found that the consumers rather liked it.

Because of the wine's bracing acidity and oceanic minerality it should be considered to be the ultimate partner to raw shellfish.
grapes: Arinto de Bucelas, Loureiro, Alvarinho, Azal, Avesso, Batoca
interesting_facts: ['Growers quite often plant their vines of telephone poles of large walls in order to grow fruit and vegetables beneath the vines.', 'Vinho Verde is a wine intended to be consumed young.', "15% of Portugal's natural viticultural area is dedicated to the production of Vinho Verde."]
flavor_words: earth, oak, non_oak

wine: Casa de Santar Vinha dos Amores Touriga Nacional 2013
wine_style_description:
Dão red wines come from a wide variety of grapes. They include Touriga Nacional, Alfrocheiro, Tinta Roriz, Jaen, Baga, Bastardo and Tinta Pinheira. The wines can range from thin to full-bodied due to multiple altitudes that these wines are grown in.

The wines normally are packed with plum and cherry flavors which are supported by firm tannins. They pair well with a wide range of food making them an easy choice for a dinner.

Being surrounded by mountains on all sides has its advantages. The Dão region is protected from the climate of the continent and from the ocean. The elevation also gives the wine much of its character. Elevation ranges between 600 feet to 3,000 feet at some points.

Most vineyards have small plots dotted through various hillsides and elevations. The soil is very poor making for stronger vines that can survive the shifts from cool nights to hot days.

The region is still considered off the beaten path and great value can be found in many of the wines. The lusher wines have the ability to age for up to 20 years or possibly more.
grapes: Touriga Nacional
interesting_facts: ['Dão nobre (means noble Dão), this is saved for reserve wines.', 'Garrafeira requires wines to be 0.5% higher in alcohol and requires two or more years spent in oak.', 'Tinta Roriz is an indigenous grape to the region. In Spain it is known as Tempranillo.', 'Touriga Nacional, the main component of port, originated in this region.']
flavor_words: oak, black_fruit, earth, non_oak, red_fruit, spices, floral, vegetal, microbio, dried_fruit, tropical_fruit, citrus_fruit

wine_style_description:
The Alentejo region covers approximately a third of Portugal, producing red wines that are easy-drinking and fruit-forward.

Aragonez is the most widely-planted red grape in the region, which produces full-bodied, budget friendly red wines. Castelao, Trincadeira are also widely planted. Frequently, wines from this region are blends of several grapes.

Although traditional Portuguese grape varieties dominate the region, many red wines from Alentejo also incorporate international grape varieties such as Syrah and Cabernet Sauvignon.

The region produces ripe, full bodied and fruit forward wines that are a product of the hot, inland region. The wines are often described as “New World” in style.

Due to the reliable climate, wines from Alentejo combine quality with affordability, offering great bang for the buck. It offers some of the best value and quality for the money of any European wine region.

Wine from this region pairs excellently with hearty, full-bodied dishes.
grapes: Aragonez, Castelao, Trincadeira
interesting_facts: ['Aragonez, the most widely planted grape in Alentejo region, is also known as Tempranillo.', 'Vineyard land in Alentejo is among the most expensive in all of Portugal.', 'The region of Alentejo is noted for its extensive cork production.']
flavor_words: oak, black_fruit, earth, non_oak, spices, red_fruit, dried_fruit, microbio, tropical_fruit, citrus_fruit, floral

wine_style_description:
Vinho Verde is a widely consumed white wine from Northern Portugal. The wine tends to be made from local grapes such as Alvarinho (Albarino), Loureiro, Arinto, and Azal.

Vinho Verde is a light, refreshing wine with lots of floral and green fruit notes. The wine often has a slight carbonation to it, though not enough that it could be referred to as a sparkling wine.

A Vinho Verde region was established in 1908, though the area didn't receive its Denominação de Origem Controlada (DOC) until 1984. The wine is thought to have originated in the Minho province in the far north of Portugal.

The carbonation in the bottle occurs from a process called malolactic fermentation, and while this is typically considered to be a defect in the wine the Vinho Verde producers found that the consumers rather liked it.

Because of the wine's bracing acidity and oceanic minerality it should be considered to be the ultimate partner to raw shellfish.
grapes: Arinto de Bucelas, Loureiro, Alvarinho, Azal, Avesso, Batoca
interesting_facts: ['Growers quite often plant their vines of telephone poles of large walls in order to grow fruit and vegetables beneath the vines.', 'Vinho Verde is a wine intended to be consumed young.', "15% of Portugal's natural viticultural area is dedicated to the production of Vinho Verde."]
flavor_words: oak, citrus_fruit, tree_fruit, spices, earth, non_oak, dried_fruit, microbio

wine: Herdade dos Grous Alentejano Reserva Branco 2019
wine_style_description:
Southern Portugal is far better known for its reds than its whites, but that doesn't mean that there aren't great bottles to be found. The dryer, hotter climate makes yielding precious acidic wine more challenging than it would be in the north.

The fabulous coastal region of Alentejo produces some excellent wine from the Antão Vaz grape, which is known for being acidic, zesty and tropical fruit-heavy.

Dry and hot are two words that commonly describe the growing regions of Southern Portugal. With as little as 23 inches of rainfall per year and summer temperatures often in excess of 100F, it's easy to see why it's considered difficult to grow great white wine.

While this area is more commonly known for reds, Antão Vaz is a white grape that has won plaudits across the wine world. Thick skinned and often similar to a lightly oaked chardonnay, it's the flagship wine of the Vidigueira region.

The wines of Southern Portugal love seafood, and work extremely well with some fresh fish, nice oily sardines or seafood paella.
grapes: Malvasia, Fernao Pires
interesting_facts: ["The Alentejo region is far more well known for producing grain, and is unofficially called Portugal's “bread basket”.", 'Portugal is currently the 12th largest wine producing country in the world.', "Southern Portugal is far better known for producing cork than producing wine. It makes over one third of the world's natural bottle stoppers."]
flavor_words: oak, tree_fruit, citrus_fruit, microbio, non_oak, earth, spices, tropical_fruit, vegetal, floral, black_fruit, red_fruit

wine: Bacalhôa Península de Setúbal Quinta da Bacalhôa Cabernet Sauvignon 2018
wine_style_description:
Just like in the north, the red wines of Southern Portugal are experiencing a Renaissance right now. These wines are typically fruity and easy to enjoy.

The regions of Alentejo and Ribatejo are leading the charge making delicious wine that anyone can enjoy.

While Northern Portugal is making amazing wines in small quantities, Southern Portugal is producing delicious, easy-drinking red wines in large quantities.

The region of Alentejo is on the forefront of this movement. The sprawling farms have allowed them to make soft, delicious wines from local grape varieties.

The region of Ribatejo is also making approachable, fun wines, but they use French grapes much more than Alentejo. Cabernet Sauvignon, Syrah, and Merlot are often found along with local grapes. White grapes are still more common in the area, but there is so much potential in the red wines.
grapes: Baga, Castelao
interesting_facts: ["Over half of the world's supply of cork is grown in Portugal.", 'With its bulk wine production, the region of Estremadura produces more wine than any other region in Portugal.', 'The region of Estremadura is known locally as Oeste, which means West.', 'The soil in much of Southern Portugal is alluvial, which is very fertile and perfect for getting lots of fruit.', 'Traditional wine in the Alentejo region is aged in clay pots.', 'A large portion of the wine in Southern Portugal is made in cooperatives that make wine for many producers at the same time.']
flavor_words: oak, black_fruit, earth, spices, non_oak, red_fruit, microbio, floral, dried_fruit, vegetal, tree_fruit, citrus_fruit, tropical_fruit

wine_style_description:
Douro Red wines range in style from light and fruity to lush and smooth to dark and dense with flavors of mature dark fruit, with herbal and schist.

The wines are often and inky purple due to the thickening of the skins from the intense summer heat of the region.

Most of the best made reds from the region come from the larger port houses where the skill of the winemakers go back for generations. The wines tend to be an incredible value for the time being but costs are slowly increasing due to the amazing blends coming from the area.

The first time one sees the Douro region they will always ask themselves, how can wine be made in such rugged terrain. It is also an amazingly beautiful area, with hillsides covered in terraced vineyards. Most larger winemakers have also started converting their areas into tourist destinations and wine hotels.

Grapes include the Touriga Francesa, Tinta Roriz, Touriga Nacional and Tinta Barroca. Older vineyards still contain many less used vine varieties which makes their annual efforts less predictable, but allowing for unexpected surprises yielding unique, complex wines.
grapes: Touriga Nacional, Tinta Roriz, Touriga Francesa
interesting_facts: ['The Douro Valley is the home of Port wine.', 'There is evidence as early as the 3rd century AD of winegrowing in the region.', 'Temperatures in the Douro Valley often reach above 100 degrees F in the summer months. This lends to the inky color of the red wines, whose skin is thicker than cool climate grapes.']
flavor_words: black_fruit, non_oak, oak, vegetal, earth, microbio

wine_style_description:
Arguably the most famous white wine from Northern Portugal is Vinho Verde (“Green Wine”) from the Minho region in the far north of the country. The other dominant region in Northern Portugal is Douro, which is home to some fabulous port wines.

Northern Portugal is big Alvarinho country, and the wonderfully crisp, almost effervescent Vinho Verde is most commonly made from this grape.

Northern Portugal is known for cheap, refreshing white wines in the coastal areas, and beautiful ports and red table wines inland in the higher ground.

White wine from this region tends to showcase a lot of citrus and, given the close proximity to the Atlantic Ocean, a lot of minerality. Vinho Verde is known for often having a light carbonation that tends to be added after the fermentation.

Wines from these regions are cheap and often represent excellent value for money! The wines live for seafood and go excellently with some cod, a fresh fish taco or a shrimp salad.
grapes: Arinto de Bucelas, Loureiro, Alvarinho, Azal, Avesso, Batoca
interesting_facts: ['The good whites from Northern Portugal are considered among the best value in wine.', 'Some other white grapes from these regions are Arinto, Loureiro, and Trajadura.', 'Portugal is currently the 12th largest wine producing country in the world.']

wine: Monte Cascas Grande Reserva Alentejano Tinto 2014
wine_style_description:
Just like in the north, the red wines of Southern Portugal are experiencing a Renaissance right now. These wines are typically fruity and easy to enjoy.

The regions of Alentejo and Ribatejo are leading the charge making delicious wine that anyone can enjoy.

While Northern Portugal is making amazing wines in small quantities, Southern Portugal is producing delicious, easy-drinking red wines in large quantities.

The region of Alentejo is on the forefront of this movement. The sprawling farms have allowed them to make soft, delicious wines from local grape varieties.

The region of Ribatejo is also making approachable, fun wines, but they use French grapes much more than Alentejo. Cabernet Sauvignon, Syrah, and Merlot are often found along with local grapes. White grapes are still more common in the area, but there is so much potential in the red wines.
grapes: Baga, Castelao
interesting_facts: ["Over half of the world's supply of cork is grown in Portugal.", 'With its bulk wine production, the region of Estremadura produces more wine than any other region in Portugal.', 'The region of Estremadura is known locally as Oeste, which means West.', 'The soil in much of Southern Portugal is alluvial, which is very fertile and perfect for getting lots of fruit.', 'Traditional wine in the Alentejo region is aged in clay pots.', 'A large portion of the wine in Southern Portugal is made in cooperatives that make wine for many producers at the same time.']
flavor_words: oak, black_fruit, earth, non_oak, red_fruit, spices, floral, dried_fruit, vegetal, microbio

wine_style_description:
Vinho Verde is a widely consumed white wine from Northern Portugal. The wine tends to be made from local grapes such as Alvarinho (Albarino), Loureiro, Arinto, and Azal.

Vinho Verde is a light, refreshing wine with lots of floral and green fruit notes. The wine often has a slight carbonation to it, though not enough that it could be referred to as a sparkling wine.

A Vinho Verde region was established in 1908, though the area didn't receive its Denominação de Origem Controlada (DOC) until 1984. The wine is thought to have originated in the Minho province in the far north of Portugal.

The carbonation in the bottle occurs from a process called malolactic fermentation, and while this is typically considered to be a defect in the wine the Vinho Verde producers found that the consumers rather liked it.

Because of the wine's bracing acidity and oceanic minerality it should be considered to be the ultimate partner to raw shellfish.
grapes: Arinto de Bucelas, Loureiro, Alvarinho, Azal, Avesso, Batoca
interesting_facts: ['Growers quite often plant their vines of telephone poles of large walls in order to grow fruit and vegetables beneath the vines.', 'Vinho Verde is a wine intended to be consumed young.', "15% of Portugal's natural viticultural area is dedicated to the production of Vinho Verde."]
flavor_words: citrus_fruit, tree_fruit, earth, non_oak, microbio, vegetal, spices

wine_style_description:
Arguably the most famous white wine from Northern Portugal is Vinho Verde (“Green Wine”) from the Minho region in the far north of the country. The other dominant region in Northern Portugal is Douro, which is home to some fabulous port wines.

Northern Portugal is big Alvarinho country, and the wonderfully crisp, almost effervescent Vinho Verde is most commonly made from this grape.

Northern Portugal is known for cheap, refreshing white wines in the coastal areas, and beautiful ports and red table wines inland in the higher ground.

White wine from this region tends to showcase a lot of citrus and, given the close proximity to the Atlantic Ocean, a lot of minerality. Vinho Verde is known for often having a light carbonation that tends to be added after the fermentation.

Wines from these regions are cheap and often represent excellent value for money! The wines live for seafood and go excellently with some cod, a fresh fish taco or a shrimp salad.
grapes: Arinto de Bucelas, Loureiro, Alvarinho, Azal, Avesso, Batoca
interesting_facts: ['The good whites from Northern Portugal are considered among the best value in wine.', 'Some other white grapes from these regions are Arinto, Loureiro, and Trajadura.', 'Portugal is currently the 12th largest wine producing country in the world.']
suggested_food_pairining: Shellfish, Appetizers and snacks, Lean fish, Cured Meat
flavor_words: earth, tree_fruit, citrus_fruit, tropical_fruit, vegetal, microbio, floral, oak, spices, red_fruit, black_fruit, non_oak

wine_style_description:
Southern Portugal is far better known for its reds than its whites, but that doesn't mean that there aren't great bottles to be found. The dryer, hotter climate makes yielding precious acidic wine more challenging than it would be in the north.

The fabulous coastal region of Alentejo produces some excellent wine from the Antão Vaz grape, which is known for being acidic, zesty and tropical fruit-heavy.

Dry and hot are two words that commonly describe the growing regions of Southern Portugal. With as little as 23 inches of rainfall per year and summer temperatures often in excess of 100F, it's easy to see why it's considered difficult to grow great white wine.

While this area is more commonly known for reds, Antão Vaz is a white grape that has won plaudits across the wine world. Thick skinned and often similar to a lightly oaked chardonnay, it's the flagship wine of the Vidigueira region.

The wines of Southern Portugal love seafood, and work extremely well with some fresh fish, nice oily sardines or seafood paella.
grapes: Malvasia, Fernao Pires
interesting_facts: ["The Alentejo region is far more well known for producing grain, and is unofficially called Portugal's “bread basket”.", 'Portugal is currently the 12th largest wine producing country in the world.', "Southern Portugal is far better known for producing cork than producing wine. It makes over one third of the world's natural bottle stoppers."]
flavor_words: tree_fruit, oak, citrus_fruit, earth, microbio, non_oak, spices, tropical_fruit, vegetal, black_fruit, red_fruit, floral, dried_fruit

wine: Herdade do Sobroso Cellar Selection Tinto 2020
wine_style_description:
The Alentejo region covers approximately a third of Portugal, producing red wines that are easy-drinking and fruit-forward.

Aragonez is the most widely-planted red grape in the region, which produces full-bodied, budget friendly red wines. Castelao, Trincadeira are also widely planted. Frequently, wines from this region are blends of several grapes.

Although traditional Portuguese grape varieties dominate the region, many red wines from Alentejo also incorporate international grape varieties such as Syrah and Cabernet Sauvignon.

The region produces ripe, full bodied and fruit forward wines that are a product of the hot, inland region. The wines are often described as “New World” in style.

Due to the reliable climate, wines from Alentejo combine quality with affordability, offering great bang for the buck. It offers some of the best value and quality for the money of any European wine region.

Wine from this region pairs excellently with hearty, full-bodied dishes.
grapes: Aragonez, Castelao, Trincadeira
interesting_facts: ['Aragonez, the most widely planted grape in Alentejo region, is also known as Tempranillo.', 'Vineyard land in Alentejo is among the most expensive in all of Portugal.', 'The region of Alentejo is noted for its extensive cork production.']
flavor_words: oak, black_fruit, red_fruit, spices, non_oak, earth, microbio, dried_fruit, tree_fruit, citrus_fruit, floral

wine_style_description:
The Alentejo region covers approximately a third of Portugal, producing red wines that are easy-drinking and fruit-forward.

Aragonez is the most widely-planted red grape in the region, which produces full-bodied, budget friendly red wines. Castelao, Trincadeira are also widely planted. Frequently, wines from this region are blends of several grapes.

Although traditional Portuguese grape varieties dominate the region, many red wines from Alentejo also incorporate international grape varieties such as Syrah and Cabernet Sauvignon.

The region produces ripe, full bodied and fruit forward wines that are a product of the hot, inland region. The wines are often described as “New World” in style.

interesting_facts: ['Aragonez, the most widely planted grape in Alentejo region, is also known as Tempranillo.', 'Vineyard land in Alentejo is among the most expensive in all of Portugal.', 'The region of Alentejo is noted for its extensive cork production.']

wine_style_description:
Douro Red wines range in style from light and fruity to lush and smooth to dark and dense with flavors of mature dark fruit, with herbal and schist.

The wines are often and inky purple due to the thickening of the skins from the intense summer heat of the region.

Most of the best made reds from the region come from the larger port houses where the skill of the winemakers go back for generations. The wines tend to be an incredible value for the time being but costs are slowly increasing due to the amazing blends coming from the area.

The first time one sees the Douro region they will always ask themselves, how can wine be made in such rugged terrain. It is also an amazingly beautiful area, with hillsides covered in terraced vineyards. Most larger winemakers have also started converting their areas into tourist destinations and wine hotels.

Grapes include the Touriga Francesa, Tinta Roriz, Touriga Nacional and Tinta Barroca. Older vineyards still contain many less used vine varieties which makes their annual efforts less predictable, but allowing for unexpected surprises yielding unique, complex wines.
grapes: Touriga Nacional, Tinta Roriz, Touriga Francesa
interesting_facts: ['The Douro Valley is the home of Port wine.', 'There is evidence as early as the 3rd century AD of winegrowing in the region.', 'Temperatures in the Douro Valley often reach above 100 degrees F in the summer months. This lends to the inky color of the red wines, whose skin is thicker than cool climate grapes.']
flavor_words: oak, black_fruit, non_oak, red_fruit, spices, earth, floral, dried_fruit, microbio

wine_style_description:
Dão red wines come from a wide variety of grapes. They include Touriga Nacional, Alfrocheiro, Tinta Roriz, Jaen, Baga, Bastardo and Tinta Pinheira. The wines can range from thin to full-bodied due to multiple altitudes that these wines are grown in.

The wines normally are packed with plum and cherry flavors which are supported by firm tannins. They pair well with a wide range of food making them an easy choice for a dinner.

Being surrounded by mountains on all sides has its advantages. The Dão region is protected from the climate of the continent and from the ocean. The elevation also gives the wine much of its character. Elevation ranges between 600 feet to 3,000 feet at some points.

Most vineyards have small plots dotted through various hillsides and elevations. The soil is very poor making for stronger vines that can survive the shifts from cool nights to hot days.

The region is still considered off the beaten path and great value can be found in many of the wines. The lusher wines have the ability to age for up to 20 years or possibly more.
grapes: Touriga Nacional
interesting_facts: ['Dão nobre (means noble Dão), this is saved for reserve wines.', 'Garrafeira requires wines to be 0.5% higher in alcohol and requires two or more years spent in oak.', 'Tinta Roriz is an indigenous grape to the region. In Spain it is known as Tempranillo.', 'Touriga Nacional, the main component of port, originated in this region.']
flavor_words: oak, earth, non_oak, black_fruit, red_fruit, spices, floral, dried_fruit

Vinho Verde is a light, refreshing wine with lots of floral and green fruit notes. The wine often has a slight carbonation to it, though not enough that it could be referred to as a sparkling wine.

A Vinho Verde region was established in 1908, though the area didn't receive its Denominação de Origem Controlada (DOC) until 1984. The wine is thought to have originated in the Minho province in the far north of Portugal.

The carbonation in the bottle occurs from a process called malolactic fermentation, and while this is typically considered to be a defect in the wine the Vinho Verde producers found that the consumers rather liked it.

Because of the wine's bracing acidity and oceanic minerality it should be considered to be the ultimate partner to raw shellfish.
grapes: Arinto de Bucelas, Loureiro, Alvarinho, Azal, Avesso, Batoca
interesting_facts: ['Growers quite often plant their vines of telephone poles of large walls in order to grow fruit and vegetables beneath the vines.', 'Vinho Verde is a wine intended to be consumed young.', "15% of Portugal's natural viticultural area is dedicated to the production of Vinho Verde."]
flavor_words: tropical_fruit, tree_fruit, citrus_fruit, vegetal, earth, microbio, oak

wine: Monte Cascas Grande Reserva Douro Tinto 2013
wine_style_description:
Douro Red wines range in style from light and fruity to lush and smooth to dark and dense with flavors of mature dark fruit, with herbal and schist.

The wines are often and inky purple due to the thickening of the skins from the intense summer heat of the region.

Most of the best made reds from the region come from the larger port houses where the skill of the winemakers go back for generations. The wines tend to be an incredible value for the time being but costs are slowly increasing due to the amazing blends coming from the area.

The first time one sees the Douro region they will always ask themselves, how can wine be made in such rugged terrain. It is also an amazingly beautiful area, with hillsides covered in terraced vineyards. Most larger winemakers have also started converting their areas into tourist destinations and wine hotels.

Grapes include the Touriga Francesa, Tinta Roriz, Touriga Nacional and Tinta Barroca. Older vineyards still contain many less used vine varieties which makes their annual efforts less predictable, but allowing for unexpected surprises yielding unique, complex wines.
grapes: Touriga Nacional, Tinta Roriz, Touriga Francesa
interesting_facts: ['The Douro Valley is the home of Port wine.', 'There is evidence as early as the 3rd century AD of winegrowing in the region.', 'Temperatures in the Douro Valley often reach above 100 degrees F in the summer months. This lends to the inky color of the red wines, whose skin is thicker than cool climate grapes.']

wine_style_description:
Arguably the most famous white wine from Northern Portugal is Vinho Verde (“Green Wine”) from the Minho region in the far north of the country. The other dominant region in Northern Portugal is Douro, which is home to some fabulous port wines.

Northern Portugal is big Alvarinho country, and the wonderfully crisp, almost effervescent Vinho Verde is most commonly made from this grape.

Northern Portugal is known for cheap, refreshing white wines in the coastal areas, and beautiful ports and red table wines inland in the higher ground.

White wine from this region tends to showcase a lot of citrus and, given the close proximity to the Atlantic Ocean, a lot of minerality. Vinho Verde is known for often having a light carbonation that tends to be added after the fermentation.

Wines from these regions are cheap and often represent excellent value for money! The wines live for seafood and go excellently with some cod, a fresh fish taco or a shrimp salad.
grapes: Arinto de Bucelas, Loureiro, Alvarinho, Azal, Avesso, Batoca
interesting_facts: ['The good whites from Northern Portugal are considered among the best value in wine.', 'Some other white grapes from these regions are Arinto, Loureiro, and Trajadura.', 'Portugal is currently the 12th largest wine producing country in the world.']
suggested_food_pairining: Shellfish, Appetizers and snacks, Lean fish, Cured Meat

wine: Herdade dos Grous Alentejano Moon Harvested 2021
wine_style_description:
Just like in the north, the red wines of Southern Portugal are experiencing a Renaissance right now. These wines are typically fruity and easy to enjoy.

The regions of Alentejo and Ribatejo are leading the charge making delicious wine that anyone can enjoy.

While Northern Portugal is making amazing wines in small quantities, Southern Portugal is producing delicious, easy-drinking red wines in large quantities.

The region of Alentejo is on the forefront of this movement. The sprawling farms have allowed them to make soft, delicious wines from local grape varieties.

The region of Ribatejo is also making approachable, fun wines, but they use French grapes much more than Alentejo. Cabernet Sauvignon, Syrah, and Merlot are often found along with local grapes. White grapes are still more common in the area, but there is so much potential in the red wines.
grapes: Baga, Castelao
interesting_facts: ["Over half of the world's supply of cork is grown in Portugal.", 'With its bulk wine production, the region of Estremadura produces more wine than any other region in Portugal.', 'The region of Estremadura is known locally as Oeste, which means West.', 'The soil in much of Southern Portugal is alluvial, which is very fertile and perfect for getting lots of fruit.', 'Traditional wine in the Alentejo region is aged in clay pots.', 'A large portion of the wine in Southern Portugal is made in cooperatives that make wine for many producers at the same time.']
flavor_words: oak, black_fruit, non_oak, spices, red_fruit, earth, microbio, floral, dried_fruit, citrus_fruit, vegetal, tree_fruit

wine_style_description:
While Port may still be king, Northern Portugal has started making world-class red wines in the regions of Douro, Dao and Bairrada.

Some of the wines are light and elegant like Burgundy's Pinot Noir. On the other hand, there are also some bold, powerful wines similar to the muscular Barolos or Bordeauxs.

Northern Portugal consists of 3 main wine regions: Douro, Dao and Bairrada. While they had underperformed for decades, they are now producing some of the most exciting wines in the world.

The Douro is definitely the highlight of Northern Portugal. This area with its steeply terraced vineyards is perfect for making quality wines. Here is where you'll find the complex cult wines that are making the region famous.

Dao is known for making fruit-filled elegant wines more similar to France's Burgundy. The cold winters and mild summers make this the perfect spot for making delicate, lovely wine.

The wines of Bairrada are almost exclusively made from the Baga grape, which is normally harsh and tough.
grapes: Touriga Nacional, Touriga Francesa
interesting_facts: ['In Portugal, a grape variety is called a “casta.”', 'The Douro is named after the Douro River that runs through the region.', 'The Douro region was officially outlined in 1756 which makes it one of the oldest official winegrowing regions in the world.', 'There are over 100 different grape varieties used to make Douro wines.', 'Almost all of the wine in Bairrada is made in one of six cooperatives where most growers send their fruit to be processed.']
flavor_words: black_fruit, oak, spices, earth, non_oak, red_fruit, floral, vegetal, microbio, dried_fruit, tree_fruit

grapes: Touriga Nacional, Touriga Franca, Tinta Roriz

wine: Dona Maria Júlio Bastos Grande Reserva 2014
wine_style_description:
The Alentejo region covers approximately a third of Portugal, producing red wines that are easy-drinking and fruit-forward.

Aragonez is the most widely-planted red grape in the region, which produces full-bodied, budget friendly red wines. Castelao, Trincadeira are also widely planted. Frequently, wines from this region are blends of several grapes.

Although traditional Portuguese grape varieties dominate the region, many red wines from Alentejo also incorporate international grape varieties such as Syrah and Cabernet Sauvignon.

The region produces ripe, full bodied and fruit forward wines that are a product of the hot, inland region. The wines are often described as “New World” in style.

Due to the reliable climate, wines from Alentejo combine quality with affordability, offering great bang for the buck. It offers some of the best value and quality for the money of any European wine region.

Wine from this region pairs excellently with hearty, full-bodied dishes.
grapes: Aragonez, Castelao, Trincadeira
interesting_facts: ['Aragonez, the most widely planted grape in Alentejo region, is also known as Tempranillo.', 'Vineyard land in Alentejo is among the most expensive in all of Portugal.', 'The region of Alentejo is noted for its extensive cork production.']
flavor_words: oak, black_fruit, spices, earth, non_oak, red_fruit, microbio, floral, vegetal, dried_fruit, citrus_fruit, tropical_fruit

interesting_facts: ['In Portugal, a grape variety is called a “casta.”', 'The Douro is named after the Douro River that runs through the region.', 'The Douro region was officially outlined in 1756 which makes it one of the oldest official winegrowing regions in the world.', 'There are over 100 different grape varieties used to make Douro wines.', 'Almost all of the wine in Bairrada is made in one of six cooperatives where most growers send their fruit to be processed.']

wine_style_description:
The Alentejo region covers approximately a third of Portugal, producing red wines that are easy-drinking and fruit-forward.

Aragonez is the most widely-planted red grape in the region, which produces full-bodied, budget friendly red wines. Castelao, Trincadeira are also widely planted. Frequently, wines from this region are blends of several grapes.

Although traditional Portuguese grape varieties dominate the region, many red wines from Alentejo also incorporate international grape varieties such as Syrah and Cabernet Sauvignon.

The region produces ripe, full bodied and fruit forward wines that are a product of the hot, inland region. The wines are often described as “New World” in style.

Due to the reliable climate, wines from Alentejo combine quality with affordability, offering great bang for the buck. It offers some of the best value and quality for the money of any European wine region.

Wine from this region pairs excellently with hearty, full-bodied dishes.
grapes: Aragonez, Castelao, Trincadeira
interesting_facts: ['Aragonez, the most widely planted grape in Alentejo region, is also known as Tempranillo.', 'Vineyard land in Alentejo is among the most expensive in all of Portugal.', 'The region of Alentejo is noted for its extensive cork production.']
flavor_words: oak, spices, red_fruit, non_oak, black_fruit, earth, dried_fruit, tree_fruit, citrus_fruit

wine: Herdade dos Grous Alentejano Moon Harvested 2020
wine_style_description:
Just like in the north, the red wines of Southern Portugal are experiencing a Renaissance right now. These wines are typically fruity and easy to enjoy.

The regions of Alentejo and Ribatejo are leading the charge making delicious wine that anyone can enjoy.

While Northern Portugal is making amazing wines in small quantities, Southern Portugal is producing delicious, easy-drinking red wines in large quantities.

The region of Alentejo is on the forefront of this movement. The sprawling farms have allowed them to make soft, delicious wines from local grape varieties.

The region of Ribatejo is also making approachable, fun wines, but they use French grapes much more than Alentejo. Cabernet Sauvignon, Syrah, and Merlot are often found along with local grapes. White grapes are still more common in the area, but there is so much potential in the red wines.

While Northern Portugal is making amazing wines in small quantities, Southern Portugal is producing delicious, easy-drinking red wines in large quantities.

The region of Ribatejo is also making approachable, fun wines, but they use French grapes much more than Alentejo. Cabernet Sauvignon, Syrah, and Merlot are often found along with local grapes. White grapes are still more common in the area, but there is so much potential in the red wines.
